title: Can you borrow books from the Library of Congress? - Quora

response.answer_text: You cannot borrow books from the Library of Congress in the way you would your local public library with some exceptions: 1. You are a member of Congress. It's Congress' library. 2. You work for the Library of Congress, do research for the Library, etc.3. You're a researcher with a Reader ID Card. This will allow you to check out materials to use in the building. Not all materials are available. You much check in materials you've borrowed before you leave. You cannot take materials home. Register for a Reader ID Card here: https://www.loc.gov/rr/readerregistration.html4. You are part of the several outreach programs run by the Library of Congress such as internship and fellowship programs sponsored by the Library, Kluge Center Fellowships, etc.  Klug Center: http://www.loc.gov/loc/kluge/fellowships/kluge.htmlNational Digital Stewardship Residency: http://www.digitalpreservation.gov/ndsr/etc. 5. You are a member of the National Library Service for the Blind and Physically Handicapped (NLS). www.loc.gov/nls NLS is a program funded by the Library for individuals with visual impairments, physical disabilities that make it difficult to hold a book for any length of time, and individuals with dyslexia. The program has its own library of digital audio and braille books, magazines, and music. The program is free to eligible patrons and the application can be found on their home page above.

In almost all cases, absolutely NOT.  You can apply for a "researcher's card" at the LC which gives you on-site access to its resources.   You can ask for a "shelf" on which to keep the materials you've requested for multi-day use and some scholars are allocated small cubicles to do their research in which they can keep LC resources during their studies. The LC uses barcodes and other tracking tools to determine the location of its holdings in its facilities, so they know to which researcher an item has been lent. Officers with the Library of Congress Police inspect bags, briefcases, etc. as people exit the building to ensure nothing in the LC collection leaves with them. With the possible exception of legislators, you simply can't take materials from the LC premises.  I cannot think of a good reason why a Representative or Senator would want to "take books out of the LC."  It's a research library (more specifically, its a collection of research libraries, see Home ), not a general purpose "circulating library" like the one in your hometown.

From Library of Congress: Research and Reference Services: Materials may only be borrowed by Congress, designated official partners, and certain government agency libraries. Additionally the Library will lend materials from its general collections to other libraries through established interlibrary loan procedures. Note that if LoC lends a book to another library on interlibrary loan, the book cannot leave the borrowing library.

Several ways have been listed in the other answers, but there is at least one more - interlibrary loan. If you are looking for something that is not available in any other library, you can request it from the Library of Congress through your local library. The local rules for interlibrary loan apply, of course, as well as LOC rules, but it can be done.

The Library of Congress is a research library and is open to the public. To access its collections, you must be 16 or older, and must have a reader card with a photo I.D. For more information: Frequently Asked Questions  | About the Library  | Library of Congress
